title: California Bill Would Prohibit Texas Abortion Ban From Being Enforced In California
description: The California bill would block the state from prosecuting people who violate abortion bans in Texas or Oklahoma.

The California Assembly passed legislation Monday that would stop the state from punishing people under the abortion bans in other states like those in Texas and Oklahoma.
Protestors rally for abortion rights in Los Angeles, California, on May 14.Anadolu Agency via Getty Images

Key Facts


The law is a direct response to a Texas abortion ban that is enforced through civil lawsuits against those who “aid or abet” the procedure—which can be filed in other states besides Texas—and has already been copied in Idaho and Oklahoma (though Idaho’s ban has been blocked in court).



The California bill, AB 1666, says a law like the Texas law, requiring civil lawsuits against people who have or “aid or abet” an abortion, is against the public policy of the state.



As a result, the California bill which passed Monday in a 56-16 vote, would bar California courts from hearing civil litigation filed under such bans enacted in other states, and would prohibit the state from enforcing any punishment under those anti-abortion laws.



Connecticut enacted a law that offers even broader legal protections against other states’ abortion bans, such as blocking the state from issuing any subpoenas based on other their abortion laws, extraditing people to other states if they’ve violated their abortion bans and having any public agency use its resources to assist other states’ abortion ban investigations.


The Connecticut law also lets people who have been prosecuted in other states for aiding or abetting an abortion sue for damages.


Washington has also enacted a law that says the state cannot “penalize, prosecute, or otherwise take adverse action” against anyone who gets an abortion or who “aid[s] or assist[s]” someone who does.




What To Watch For
The California bill still has to be passed by the state Senate and signed by Gov. Gavin Newsom (D), who has been broadly supportive of abortion rights, before it can become law. Similar bills could also pass in other states. New York lawmakers, for instance, have introduced legislation that would block law enforcement from cooperating with other states’ investigations into violations of abortion bans, and New Jersey is also considering a bill that would block people from being extradited to other states.
What We Don’t Know
How the clash between state abortion laws will play out in court. Critics of the California bill argue that it would violate the Constitution’s “full faith and credit” clause, which requires states to recognize other states’ policies. California lawmakers argue the bill doesn’t violate that clause, because the abortion bans go against the state’s public policy and the Supreme Court has previously ruled that the clause doesn’t require states to “substitute the statutes of another state for its own statutes.” It’s also unclear how necessary the law will be, as no lawsuits have yet been filed under the Texas ban against people who reside in other states. Legal experts also say it’s hard to predict how things will play out if states that ban abortion try and prosecute residents who get abortions in other states—as Missouri lawmakers have already proposed—which could violate a clause that prohibits states from passing laws that burden interstate commerce.

Key Background
California’s bill is part of a trend of Democratic-led states stepping up efforts to protect abortion rights in the face of Texas’ abortion ban and its copycats, and as the Supreme Court appears poised to overturn Roe v. Wade. A draft opinion leaked by Politico shows a majority of justices were in favor of striking down Roe and letting states ban abortion as of February, though the court’s final opinion won’t be released likely until June. California lawmakers have also moved forward with other bills like one blocking the state’s medical board from revoking the licenses of doctors who perform abortions, for instance, and the state leaders plan to put a measure on the ballot in November asking voters whether abortion rights should be enshrined in the state Constitution. Other recent state measures include New York and Oregon establishing new funds to expand abortion access and Colorado and New Jersey enacting laws codifying abortion rights.
